questions.text: What is the study of the processes in a firearm known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The study of the processes in a firearm is known as internal ballistics.

Ballistics is the science of mechanics that deals with the flight, behaviour and effects of projectiles.

Internal ballistics examines all events within the firearm, from primer ignition to projectile exit, including:

  • Propellant burn and gas generation: How powder combustion creates high-pressure gases
  • Chamber and barrel pressure dynamics: Pressure curves and their effect on projectile acceleration
  • Projectile-barrel interaction: Friction, engraving, and obturation of the bullet
  • Muzzle phenomena: Final velocity and transition of the projectile at the muzzle

Explanation of other options:

Forensic ballistics (Option A) is an umbrella term for internal, external, and terminal ballistics.

Exterior ballistics (Option C) deals with the behaviour of the projectile after leaving the barrel till it reaches the target, accounting for factors like air resistance and gravity.

Terminal ballistics (Option D) comprises the changes caused when a missile penetrates an animal or human body, including cavitation and tissue disruption.

questions.text: Which of the following is a smooth-barreled weapon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A shotgun is a smooth-barreled weapon. It is usually designed to be fired from the shoulder, which uses the energy of a fixed shell to fire several small spherical pellets called shots or a solid projectile called a slug.

choices.text: Mechanism to increase the range of shots fired

questions.text: The term 'choking' in ballistics applies to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 'Choke' refers to the intentional tapering (narrowing) of the distal 7-10 cm of a shotgun's smooth-bore barrel, reducing its diameter relative to the parallel-sided "cylinder" section
  • Function: This taper concentrates the shot load into a tighter conical pattern, producing a narrower spread of pellets on discharge.
  • Range estimation: Different choke gradations ("improved cylinder," "modified," "half-choke," "full-choke") directly influence pellet dispersion and are critical for forensic estimation of firing distance based on wound spread.
  • Forensic relevance: When examining a shotgun wound, identifying pellet dispersion and wound aperture lets a pathologist infer whether a full-choke or an improved-cylinder barrel was used, which in turn narrows down the firing distance.
  • This can thus affect the estimation of the range of firing when examining the entry wound.

Explanation of other options:

Ammunition of a shotgun (Option B) contains shot, wads, and propellant. It does not include a barrel constriction.

Barrel of a rifled gun (Option C): Rifled guns use grooves, not choke tapers.

Mechanism to increase range (Option D): Choke shapes pattern density but does not significantly alter muzzle velocity or maximum range.

questions.text: Which of the following is useful in identifying the make and model of a gun?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary markings are specific to the make and model of the gun.

Primary Markings:

  • Primary markings refer to class characteristics such as grooves, lands, calibre, and twist, which are imparted by a firearm's barrel design.
  • Rifled firearms leave their signature on the cartridge case and the bullet.
  • With all rifled firearms, as the bullet passes through the barrel, its sides are marked by the rifling (by the friction between the bullet and lands) of the barrel (primary markings; class characteristics) and cause the bullet to rotate, and these marks are most useful in identifying the make and model of gun involved.

Secondary Markings (Option B):

  • Arise from microscopic barrel defects and are used for bullet-to-barrel matching.
  • The surface of the bullet is also grooved by irregularities on the inner surface of the barrel itself (secondary markings/secondary characteristics/individual characteristics/accidental characteristics),which are specific for that particular weapon.
  • Secondary markings are used for bullet fingerprinting (Option C), a process of matching a recovered bullet to the exact firearm that fired it by comparing its unique microscopic barrel markings.

Rifling (Option D) is the process of adding spiral grooves to the inside of the barrel of a gun. The elevations between the grooves are called lands.

questions.text: What does the line in the photo indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Calibre or gauge is measured as the distance between two diametrically opposite lands.

  • The line in the image spans from one land to the opposite land, indicating the
  • It is the internal dimension of the barrel and is measured in millimetres or inches.
  • Lands (Option A) are the raised portions between the grooves in a rifled barrel.
  • Grooves (Option B) are the cut or recessed portions that impart spin

Explanation of other options:

Choke (Option D) refers to the intentional tapering (narrowing) of the distal 7-10 cm of a shotgun's smooth-bore barrel.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not found in a shotgun ammunition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A shotgun cartridge does not have a metal cylinder. It has a metal base, but the cylinder is made of cardboard.

  • The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base.
  • The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.
  • The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.
  • The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are 'wads' or pistons of felt, cardboard or plastic discs or both.

  • The projectiles are traditionally made of lead, but other metals such as steel, tungsten and bismuth are also used due to restrictions on lead or for performance reasons such as achieving higher shot velocities by reducing the mass of the shot charge.

Explanation of other options:

Wads (Option A) are non-metallic discs (felt, cardboard, or plastic) that cushion the shot column and seal propellant gases.

Percussion detonator (Option C) is the explosive element housed in the primer cup, struck by the firing pin to ignite the propellant.

Primer (Option D) is the component containing the detonator compound whose ignition produces the flame that ignites the main propellant charge.

questions.text:
Which of the following are constituents of smokeless gunpowder?
1. Nitrocellulose
2. Potassium nitrate
3. Nitroglycerine
4. Nitroguanidine
5. Sulphur
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Smokeless powder is based on nitrocellulose and often enhanced with nitroglycerine and nitroguanidine.

Various Types Of Gunpowder:

Smokeless powder:

  • Nitrocellulose (single base)
  • Nitrocellulose & Nitroglycerine (double base)
  • Nitrocellulose, Nitroglycerine and Nitroguanidine (triple base)
  • 1 gram produces 12,000 to 13,000 cc of gas.

Black Powder:

  • Potassium nitrate (75%)
  • Charcoal (15%)
  • Sulphur (10%)
  • 1 gram of powder produces 3,000 cc of gas.

Semi-smokeless powder:

  • A mixture of 80% black and 20% smokeless powder.

questions.text: Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows multiple small radio-opaque densities of equal size and shape. This suggests that the person has been shot by a smooth-bore shotgun.
  • The cartridge contained birdshot.
  • Shotguns (smooth-bore firearms) loaded with birdshot discharge multiple small pellets that scatter on impact, producing this "pellet shower" appearance.
  • Smooth-bore vs. rifled weapons: Smooth bores fire multiple pellets, and rifled barrels fire a single spin-stabilised bullet.
  • Pellet dispersion: The density and spread of pellets on imaging can help estimate firing distance (closer shots cluster, distant shots scatter more widely).

In case of firing by an Assault rifle (Option B), a Sporting rifle (Option C) or a Machine gun (Option D) (all rifled firearms), there will not be multiple pellets.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for peppering around the wound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Peppering (tattooing) occurs when partially burnt or unburnt gunpowder particles are propelled into the skin around the entry wound.
  • On ignition, most powder combusts to gas and soot, but residual grains embedded in the dermis and epidermis produce the characteristic speckled "pepper" appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Smoke (Option A): Soot from complete powder combustion deposits broadly, not in pinpoint patterns.

Primer (Option B): Small flash and residue, but does not produce the granular peppering seen with powder grains.

Pellets (Option C): shotgun pellets cause multiple puncture wounds, not superficial peppering.

questions.text: On autopsy examination of a victim of firearm injury, singeing of hair is seen around the entry wound. What is the likely distance between the gun and the victim?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hair singeing requires direct flame contact.
  • Flame from a shotgun can travel up to 15 cm, while rifled firearms reach only about 8 cm.
  • Contact vs close range: Contact wounds (< 1 cm) often show muzzle imprint and extensive soot; singeing without imprint indicates a close shot (< 15 cm).
  • Intermediate/distant shots: Between 15 cm and 1 m, only powder tattooing and soot occur, no hair burning.

questions.text: In a shotgun-injury victim, you note the rat-hole appearance of the entry wound. From what range was it most likely fired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A rat-hole appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 1 metre of range.

  • Shotgun ranges are classified as:
    • Contact and near-contact shots.
    • Close Range (up to one metre)
    • Short range (1 to 2 metres)
    • Intermediate-range (2 to 4 metres)
    • Long or Distant range(above 4 metres)
  • When a shotgun is fired, initially all the pellets move out of the barrel as a single mass up to 2 metres (Single wound of entry), after which the peripheral pellets start dispersing from 2 - 4 metres (Main wound + satellite wounds), then there will be complete dispersion beyond 4 metres (Multiple wounds of entry).
  • Rat-hole wounds: Between 30 cm to one metre, the rim of the wound is irregular and shows some scalloping, often referred to as a "rat-hole". There may be annular abrasions and bruising or "rat nibbling".

Explanation of other options:

Contact shot (Option A) produces a stellate or split wound with a clear muzzle imprint, heavy soot deposition, and true gas cavitation rather than a narrow "rat-hole."

15-30 cm (Option B) yields dense soot and powder tattooing around the entry, with limited internal gas effects and no characteristic rodent-nibbling cavitation.

1 m-2 m (Option D) fires only isolated pellets into the tissue, without soot, tattooing, or central cavitary channels, thus lacking a rat-hole appearance.

questions.text: A person has been shot by a full choke shotgun. On examination, the dispersion of pellets is 25 centimetres. The range of firing is most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The range of firing is most likely to be 10 metres. A 25 cm spread from a full-choke barrel corresponds to a 10 metre discharge distance.

Choke mechanics:

  • Full chokes constrict the muzzle exit by about 1 mm, forcing the shot into a tight cone.
  • At 10 m, this yields the observed 25 cm diameter.

Forensic practice: Always confirm with test-firing the exact make/model and ammunition; environmental factors and barrel wear can slightly alter the spread.

Explanation of other options:

12.5 m (Option A): A full-choke barrel yields ~25 cm at 10 m and ~35 cm at 15 m; at 12.5 m, you'd expect approximately 30-32 cm of spread, wider than the observed 25 cm.

50 m (Option C): Beyond 20 m, full-choke patterns exceed 45 cm and continue to widen. At 50 m, shot clouds typically disperse over a metre, not a compact 25 cm circle.

100 m (Option D): At such distances, pellets scatter uniformly, producing isolated perforations rather than any tight cluster. A 25 cm spread is impossible at 100 m.

questions.text: What is the retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm is known as backspatter.

  • In contact shots and sometimes in close shots, the muzzle blast and the negative pressure in the barrel following discharge may suck blood, hair, fragments of tissues and cloth fibres several cm back inside the barrel called "back spatter" → Helps in identification of weapon.
  • Forward spatter: Splashing of blood & tissue fragments through the wound of exit.

Explanation of other options:

Blowback phenomenon (Option A): This is seen at the entry wound in a contact shot against a bone, where the gases rebound against the bone and exit through the entry wound, creating a stellate-shaped margin at the entry wound.

Retro dispersion (Option B) and backwards scatter (Option C) are not effects seen in firearm injuries.

questions.text: The following is a victim of firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a wound of entry surrounded by tattooing (peppering). There is no blackening (smudging). That means the target was beyond the reach of the smoke/soot but within the range of powder particles, i.e., intermediate range.

  • Particle penetration depth: These powder grains penetrate only into the epidermis and superficial dermis, producing abrasions and microscopic haemorrhages visible under magnification.
  • Absence of gas effects: Unlike contact or near-contact shots, there is no muzzle imprint, stellate tearing, or gas cavitation at this range.

Explanation of other options:

Close range (Option A) would exhibit a halo of soot and possible hair singeing in addition to tattooing.

Point blank (Option C) produces contact-shot signs: muzzle imprint, blackening, and internal gas effects.

Distant (Option D) shows a clean entry without any tattooing or soot marks.

questions.text: All the following bullets are expanding bullets except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fully jacketed bullets encase the lead core completely in a metal jacket, preventing expansion and classifying them as non-expanding.

  • Dum-dum bullets (Option A) or expanding bullets are bullets that expand or flatten easily in the human body, such as bullets with a hard envelope that does not entirely cover the core or is pierced with incisions.
  • Different Types of Expanding Bullets:
    1. Hollow point (Option B)/Express bullet (Option C): It is a jacketed bullet with a hole/pit in the tip
    2. Soft point/soft-nosed bullet: It is a jacketed bullet, whereas the lead core extends forward of the jacket (Semi-jacketed bullet).
  • In these bullets, lead is exposed, which gets mushroomed out on hitting the target, giving rise to greater tissue damage.

Reference:

https://casebook.icrc.org/a_to_z/glossary/dum-dum-bullets

choices.text: Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy
Scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray analysis

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most sensitive for the detection of gunpowder residue?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis (SEM-EDX) is the most sensitive as well as the most commonly used test for the detection of gunshot residue.

  • SEM-EDX combines high resolution imaging with elemental analysis, allowing the detection and mapping of characteristic primer residues (lead, barium, antimony) at the micron scale. Its sensitivity and specificity exceed bulk analysis methods.
  • Sample collection: Adhesive stubs or tape lifts are typically taken from the shooter’s hands, clothing, or nearby surfaces and examined under SEM-EDX.

Tests for the detection of gunpowder residue:

Explanation of other options:

Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Option A): A variant of Flameless atomic absorption spectroscopy. It analyses dissolved samples for elemental composition but lacks spatial resolution to confirm particulate morphology.

Neutron activation analysis (Option B): Highly sensitive for trace elements but destructive and unable to distinguish GSR morphology.

Flameless atomic absorption spectroscopy (Option D): Measures bulk metal concentrations but cannot differentiate GSR particles from environmental contamination.

questions.text: The fragments of lead from a bullet break off the lead core and are hurled out into the surrounding tissues. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lead snowstorm is the phenomenon caused by a firearm wound, when lead fragments are stripped from the bullet as it travels through the body, causing multiple fragments to be present along the wound track.

Lead snowstorm:

  • X-rays of individuals shot with high-velocity rifle ammunition show a characteristic radiologic picture, the so-called "lead snowstorm".
  • As the expanding bullet moves through the body, fragments of lead break off the core and are hurled out into the surrounding tissues.
  • An X-ray shows scores of small radiopaque bullet fragments scattered along the wound track (the lead snowstorm)
  • These fragments vary from dust-like to large, irregular pieces of metal.
  • A rifle bullet does not have to hit bone for this phenomenon to occur. Fragmentation occurs purely from the bullet's velocity and construction.
  • This pattern is absent with most handgun bullets and with full-metal-jacketed rifle rounds, which resist core breakup.

Lead snowstorm phenomenon

Explanation of other options:

Wound peppering (Option B): Penetration of unburnt powder grains into the skin around an entry wound, not metallic fragments.

Sparrow foot (Option C): A dermatological term unrelated to ballistic trauma.

Birdshot (Option D) refers to shotgun pellets, not bullet core fragmentation.

choices.text: The Bullet should be picked up with metallic toothed forceps
The Bullet should be removed with bare hands
Bullet should be packed in leakproof packaging made of hard plastic
The Bullet should be wiped with a clean cloth to remove dirt

questions.text: While recovering a bullet from the crime scene, which of the following should be followed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The bullet should be packed in leak-proof packaging made of hard plastic.
  • The bullets/fragments should be recovered as completely and intact as possible, either with the gloved fingers or with rubber-tipped forceps to avoid any scratching or defacing done inadvertently during handling. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Double heavy-duty gloves should be worn while handling projectiles or other foreign objects (due to the risk of contamination)
  • Prior radiography should be conducted in order to localise bullets/pellets and to evaluate likely ensuing hazards.
  • Rubber-tipped extractor for the recovery and handling of bullets/fragments should be employed.
  • The projectile should be examined for any trace evidence, such as fibres, glass pieces, paint, etc. Then it may be dried in the open air, if need be. Wiping with a cloth may remove or smear trace evidence and alter the bullet's surface. (Option D ruled out)
  • Pack the bullet/fragments, etc., into a hard plastic container padded with any soft material like tissue paper or paper towels rather than an envelope to prevent accidental puncture through the envelope and consequent injury.

questions.text: The victim gives a history of being shot at while trying to prevent an armed burglary. Identify the type of injury.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is suggestive of a bullet graze.

Bullet graze:

  • The bullet just hits the skin only at an angle and goes off from the site, without any penetration or wound of entry.
  • It produces an abrasion or a laceration depending on the thickness of the skin involved.

Explanation of other options:

Bullet bruise (Option A): The bullet here just hits the skin only and drops down to the ground, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces a bruise alone at the site of impact. Usually seen when an individual with a bulletproof vest is shot at.

Bullet wipe (Option D): Also known as a grease collar, seen around the wound of entry, which is derived from the residue from the barrel.

Bullet mark (Option C): Nonstandard term; not recognised in forensic classification.

choices.text: Residual from the barrel of the gun

questions.text: What is a bullet wipe?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bullet wipe is due to the grease, soot or debris from the barrel of the gun.

  • While examining the clothing of a victim of bullet injury, there is a deposition of various residues surrounding the entrance defect at various ranges known as bullet wipe.
  • It helps in determining the wounds of the inlet and outlet on the body.
  • A "bullet wipe"(Dirt ring/projectile wipe ring) is a grey or black ring around the wound of entry of a bullet.
  • The ring is formed by and contains bullet lubricant, byproducts of propellant, traces of bullet metal and residue in the gun barrel from previous use.
  • It is due to wiping of the substances from the bullet surface as it passes through the skin, like grease, barrel debris, soil particles, etc.

Explanation of other options:

Blackening (Option B): A layer of soot around the wound, not the mixed residues of bullet wipe.

Gutter fracture of skull (Option C): A skull fracture type seen in cranial injuries, not a soft-tissue ring.

Tattooing (Option D): Powder-particle stippling in skin, not barrel-residue transfer.

questions.text: What is the bullet recovered from the victim of a homicidal shooting known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A bullet collected at surgery or autopsy, from the body of a victim, alive or dead, is called a crime bullet. In other words, a crime bullet is recovered from the body of a victim.

Explanation of other options:

Test bullet (Option B) is fired from the suspect firearm into a target (e.g., a bag in a box) so it can be retrieved and examined. Its rifling impressions, both class (grooves and lands) and individual microscopic marks, are compared with those on the crime bullet to identify the weapon.

Exhibit bullet (Option C) is a crime/test bullet, which is presented in the court as evidence.

Suspect bullet (Option D): Not a standard forensic term; bullets are classified by origin (crime or test), not by suspect status.

questions.text: During a radiological examination, a radiologist identifies a bullet present in the body surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. What type of bullet is it called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The kind of bullet identified by the radiologist, as explained in the given scenario, is known as a souvenir bullet.

  • A souvenir bullet is the one that has been lodged in the body for a long time, with no fresh bleeding around it and surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule.
  • They can be visualised on X-rays.
  • They are usually a result of a bullet lodging in an inaccessible space, which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. E.g., Bullet in the spine.

Explanation of other options:

Tandem bullet/Piggyback bullet (Option A and Option B) occurs when a round sticks in the barrel and, upon a second firing, carries the lodged bullet along with the new one into the target. This typically results from a weapon malfunction, defective ammunition, or prolonged storage or heat exposure preventing proper ejection.

Incendiary bullets (Option C): The tip of the bullet contains white phosphorus. Used to cause a fire in the target (e.g., to ignite a fuel tank).

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Puppe's rule: Helps in determining the sequence of bullets that hit the skull when there are multiple bullet injuries to the skull. The fracture line resulting from the latter bullet will typically stop at the previously formed one.
  • Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact, as the evaluation of the wound as an entry or exit wound and the range of firing, etc., becomes difficult.
  • Rayalaseema phenomenon: Here, a person is killed by a stab injury and a bullet is implanted inside to mislead the investigation.
  • Ewing's postulates: Establishes a relationship between trauma and new growth.

questions.text: The sequence of bullet injuries in the following image can be identified by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sequence of gunshots in this case is 1 → 2 → 3 according to Puppe's rule.

  • Puppe's rule: It states that the path of a second fracture line does not cross the path of an existing fracture line that appears or was caused before it. This helps the forensic expert determine the chronology (order) in which the bullets were lodged into the skull.
  • Puppe's rule is used in forensic examination of skull fractures caused by multiple blunt force impacts as well, and it is not limited to the examination of bullet injuries only.

Explanation of other options:

Hess's rule (Option B) or Rule of Haase is used to estimate the gestational age of a foetus by crown-heel length.

Kassowitz's law (Option C) is an empirical observation used in the context of congenital syphilis stating that the greater the duration between the infection of the mother and conception, the better the outcome for the infant.

questions.text: What is a Molotov cocktail?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A Molotov cocktail is an incendiary bomb that is thrown by hand.

  • A bottle is filled with gasoline or petrol or diesel, or any other flammable material, and a rag to serve as a wick.
  • The wick is lit and thrown at the target.
  • Various acids and chemicals are sometimes added to increase the destructive effects.

Explanation of other options:

Alcoholic poisoning (Option A): Ingestion-based toxicity, not an explosive device.

Acid bomb (Option C): A container of corrosive acid designed to injure via chemical burns, not to ignite fires.

Rifled firearm (Option D): A gun with spiral grooves; not an improvised explosive.

questions.text: Which is the most severely injured organ in blast injuries underwater and air respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Underwater blast: The intestines are the hardest hit because gas-filled organs absorb the shock wave most severely.
  • Air blast: The lungs sustain the worst damage due to the air-tissue interface within the chest.
  • A blast causes the most damage at an interface between tissues in contact with the atmosphere, which is why the lung usually suffers the most severe damage.
  • The gastrointestinal system suffers from the effects of a blast because, like the lung, it contains air and gases and is thus not a uniform medium for transit of the shock wave.
  • Victims of explosions in water suffer a reverse order of gastrointestinal to lung damage.

questions.text: Following a blast, a man was brought from the scene to the emergency room with multiple small puncture wounds to the right side of the chest, below the nipple and multiple small abrasions and bruising over the left lower abdomen. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given history of multiple small puncture wounds to the right side of the chest, below the nipple and multiple small abrasions and bruising over the left lower abdomen is highly suggestive of blast injuries sustained due to flying missiles.

  • Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion, causing a sudden increase or decrease in atmospheric pressure.

Air blast injuries are divided into the following 5 categories:

  1. Primary blast injuries:
    • Caused by the direct pressure effects of the blast wave/shock wave on the victim.
  2. Secondary blast injuries:
    • Caused by flying missiles that strike people
    • Marshal's Triad (Body stippling):
      • Combination of Abrasions + Contusions, + Punctate lacerations
  3. Tertiary blast injuries:
    • Caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects
  4. Quaternary blast injuries:
    • All other injuries not included in the first three classes
    • These include flash burns, crush injuries and respiratory injuries
  5. Quinary blast injuries:
    • Illnesses, injuries or diseases caused by chemical, biological or radiological substances

Explanation of other options:

Blast of air (Option B) or a blast wave causes primary injuries, which involve internal organs without external injury.

Explosion burns (Option C): When the bomb explodes, the temperature of the explosive gases can exceed 2000°C, and the heat radiated momentarily can cause flash burns. It is a quaternary type of blast injury.

Building collapse (Option D) can cause crush injuries, which is a quaternary blast injury.
